title: Top 10 films of 2021
text:
Summer of Soul

Best movie of 2021 — or 1969? You could make a case for Summer of Soul as either, given that it documents the Harlem Cultural Festival, staged 52 years ago. But the film shot back then of a firmament of black music stars on goosebump-inducing form — Sly Stone, Nina Simone, Stevie Wonder, more — only fully surfaced this year. More relevant still, it is musician/director Ahmir “Questlove” Thompson who sculpts the archive into a vivid panorama of sight, sound, time and place. The result is irresistible.

On Disney Plus

The Father

A single flat in north-west London and a small cast led by Anthony Hopkins giving maybe the greatest performance of a career filled with them: such are the essentials of The Father, Florian Zeller's brilliantly controlled adaptation of his stage play, a portrait of dementia that explodes at once into a dazzling, fractured detective story and raging, unshakeable elegy.

On Amazon Prime, iTunes and other digital platforms

Florian Zeller: ‘I wanted to be as far as possible from the theatrical process'

Petite Maman

“Little Daddy”, Olivia Colman calls Anthony Hopkins in The Father. Céline Sciamma's Petite Maman makes the perfect mirror image — another story of children and parents with a built-in puzzle, but this one dusted with joy. In 72 exquisite minutes, the story holds Proustian moments and a plot twist big enough to fuel a blockbuster.

In cinemas now and on Mubi from February 4

7 Prisoners

A plot twist of sorts lies too at the dark heart of the scalding Brazilian thriller 7 Prisoners. To begin, the film — a tale of modern slavery — feels like knuckle-hard social realism. But in time, it shape-shifts into something more potent still, a Brechtian drama that asks uneasy questions of us all — not least film lovers.

On Netflix

Licorice Pizza

As heady as a first kiss, Paul Thomas Anderson returns to the 1970s Los Angeles that inspired his manic epic of the porno business, Boogie Nights. Now, though, sweet innocence — or something like it — is the stuff of his pick-me-up tale of teenage crushes and the Hollywood dream factory. In Alana Haim and Cooper Hoffman, two stars are born.

In US cinemas now and UK cinemas from January 1

Azor

The surface of Azor, the story of a Swiss private banker and the junta in 1980 Argentina, is — like him — flawlessly controlled. Beneath, both he and it churn with unease, in a study of money and morality that calls to mind The Third Man and deserves the comparison.

On Mubi

Annette

A true one-off is hard to find but it arrived this year with the brooding rock opera Annette from maverick director Leos Carax. If Adam Driver and Marion Cotillard make quite the star-crossed couple, the show is stolen by their baby — no spoilers, but a unique creation herself — and Carax's flights of imagination.

On Mubi

Leos Carax on Annette and working with Adam Driver

Gunda

Who would have expected scenes from the real life of a Norwegian pig to yield drama this sophisticated? Captured in luminous black and white, the look of Viktor Kossakovsky's documentary is breathtaking, the strange lot of the farm animal never more compelling.

On Amazon Prime, iTunes and other digital platforms

Victor Kossakovsky on Gunda — his grunting, muddy ‘Meryl Streep'

Quo Vadis, Aida?

If Spencer's Kristen Stewart gave the best performance of the second half of 2021, she was matched early in the year by Jasna Djuricic as the title character of Quo Vadis, Aida?. As a UN interpreter in the hours ahead of the Srebrenica massacre, Djuricic is the watchful face of a haunting film.

On Curzon Home Video, Amazon Prime, iTunes and other digital platforms

Oscar-nominated Jasmila Zbanic: ‘War shrinks us as human beings'

West Side Story

And then, crashing into the last days of 2021 with a swagger and a mighty cha-cha-cha, comes Steven Spielberg and his vibrant remake of the much-loved musical. At the end of a year when movies in cinemas have made at least a tentative comeback, the return of Spielberg on this kind of form puts a gleaming cherry on the cake.
